Literature Review: The exploration of visual representations within the brain has been significantly advanced by the application of computational techniques from machine learning to neural data. This approach, known as neural decoding, has provided profound insights into how the brain processes and represents visual information. The foundational work by Kamitani and Tong (2005) demonstrated that it is possible to decode the orientation of visual stimuli from patterns of activity in the human visual cortex, marking a pivotal moment in the field. This study laid the groundwork for subsequent research that has sought to understand the complexity and behavioral relevance of visual representations. Recent advancements in multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) have further enhanced our ability to decode these representations, revealing the spatiotemporal structure of visual information processing in the brain. Studies by Haynes and Rees (2006) and Kriegeskorte et al. (2006) have shown that MVPA can be used to decode not only simple visual features but also complex objects and scenes, highlighting the robustness of visual representations to various perturbations. Moreover, research by Nishimoto et al. (2011) has demonstrated that it is possible to reconstruct dynamic visual experiences from brain activity, providing compelling evidence for the detailed nature of visual representations. The sensitivity of these representations to different mental states has also been a subject of interest. For instance, work by Harrison and Tong (2009) has shown that visual working memory can modulate the strength of visual representations in the brain, suggesting a dynamic interplay between perception and cognition. Beyond the representation of the physical world, neural decoding has illuminated how the brain instantiates internally generated states, such as during imagery and prediction. Studies by Pearson et al. (2015) and Dijkstra et al. (2017) have explored the neural correlates of visual imagery, revealing similarities and differences between imagined and perceived visual stimuli. Additionally, research by Kok et al. (2017) has investigated how the brain predicts upcoming visual information, shedding light on the predictive coding framework. The potential of neural decoding to assess the functional relevance of visual representations for human behavior is immense. Future research directions include understanding how these representations change across development and during aging, as well as uncovering their presentation in various mental disorders. The work by Park et al. (2004) on age-related changes in visual processing and by Yoon et al. (2013) on visual representations in schizophrenia exemplifies the breadth of applications for neural decoding techniques. In conclusion, neural decoding has revolutionized our understanding of visual representations in the brain, offering insights into their complexity, behavioral relevance, and dynamic nature. As computational techniques continue to evolve, the potential for further discoveries in this field is vast, promising to deepen our understanding of the neural basis of vision and cognition.
